Not sure how to read your table; what are the units of your time column, 
and what does "from Queue Completed**:" mean?

If seconds, the 23/69 totals look suspiciously like about 1-3 times the 
default socket-timeout for a non-responsive host (20 seconds).

Without adding extra logging code, you can deduce some similar data from 
the crawl.log -- the field that's of the form...

#################+####

...is the timestamp when the network-fetching began, '+' the duration of 
the network fetch. Also, the leading date on the log line is the instant 
of logging, so (missing some pre-fetch time) you can get an idea of the 
bulk of processing time from those values.

See also this FAQ entry if you're just generally wondering why crawling 
isn't going as fast as you might have hoped:

https://webarchive.jira.com/wiki/display/Heritrix/crawl+rate+considerations

If you want to dig deeper, it'd be good to know:

� what version of Heritrix?

� what happens when you isolate the URIs that seem to be slow into a 
dedicated crawl for a closer look?

- Gordon @ IA

On 7/11/11 3:39 PM, vinoth_amaranathan wrote:
>
>
> I tried to do some logging at the Toethread to find out where the avg
> amount of time is being spent per request. I found that the average time
> spent is more in fetching URIs from the BDB queues.
> Its surprising to see that the time spent was on a max 69 secs for one
> work item. Am i missing something here ?
>

> various stages of the processor chains.
